description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Daily: Kris Kobachs Quest Against Voter Fraud
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: With Cancer Screening, Better Safe Than Sorry?
description: Doctors and medical organizations often advise that past a certain age, older adults can forgo various screening tests for cancer. But many patients, no matter how old or sick they may be, are reluctant to abandon tests theyve long been told can be lifesaving.

title: Why Smoking in Films Harms Children
description: We want to believe were raising our kids to think for themselves, and not to do dumb or unhealthy things just because the cool kids are doing them.

title: New York Today: Fighting Fire in the Heat
description: Updated, 11:50 a.m.

title: Police in Europe Break Up Network Selling Illegal Horse Meat
description: GENEVA  The police in Europe have dismantled a criminal network that was selling horse meat across the Continent that was not suitable for consumption, arresting 66 people as part of a four-year investigation prompted by the discovery in Ireland of horse meat in burgers sold as beef.

title: Struggles at Procter & Gamble Draw Scrutiny of Nelson Peltz
description: Tide detergent dominated the American laundry room for decades and helped make Procter & Gamble a consumer products behemoth.

title: Afghanistan More Deadly for Women and Children, U.N. Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan has grown more deadly this year for women, children and other residents of the capital, the United Nations mission in the country said on Monday, even as the violence is expected to intensify in the coming months with no hope of peace talks any time soon.

title: Morning Agenda: Peltz Challenges Procter & Gamble
description: The biggest proxy fight against a company has begun, and its Procter & Gamble against Nelson Peltz.

title: Macron Denounces Anti-Zionism as Reinvented Form of Anti-Semitism
description: Standing at a site from which thousands of French Jews were sent to their deaths during the Holocaust, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Sunday deplored his nations wartime role in abetting murder and pledged to fight a renewed tide of anti-Semitism.

title: When Women Wont Accept Theatrical Manspreading
description: There is an animated ad playing in the subway that drives me a little up the wall. Its an anti-manspreading spot, in which a seated man with his legs wide open closes them, mostly, allowing a woman to sit beside him. So far, so good  until she daintily crosses her ankles to make herself as small as possible. Then she thanks the nice man for, as far as I can tell, no longer taking up way more than his fair share of room.

title: The Trouble With Trade School
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: California Today: Awaiting Reprieve at Big Sur
description: Good morning.

title: Russian Mansions: Retreats or Spy Nests?
description: The Obama administration ordered Russian diplomats to leave two waterfront compounds in New York and Maryland. Now, Russia wants them back.

title: BlackRock Earnings Rise 9 Percent, Buoyed by Passive Funds
description: BlackRock, the worlds largest asset management firm, said on Monday that second-quarter earnings had risen 9 percent as investors continued to pour money into the companys expanding fleet of exchange traded funds.

title: K.K.R. Lays Out a Line of Succession, a Rare Move in Private Equity
description: Few can claim as crucial a role in creating the buyout industry as Henry R. Kravis and George R. Roberts. From a small partnership that began with just $120,000, the two created the colossus now known as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the firm that bought RJR Nabisco and defined an era.

title: American Peace Activist Is Denied Entry to South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An American who helped arrange for 30 female peace activists to cross the heavily armed border between North and South Korea in 2015 has been denied entry to South Korea, officials confirmed on Monday.

title: Globes (Not Golden) Win a Film Role for a New York Landmark
description: Thanks to the great globe lights at its front door, the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen in mid-Manhattan has won a surprising new role: headquarters of The New York Times.

title: Jennifer Chen, Daniel Lee
description: Dr. Jennifer Chen and Dr. Daniel Junseung Lee were married July 15 at TriBeCa 360, an event space in New York. Pastor John Jung, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Bank of New York Mellon Hires Former Visa Head as C.E.O.
description: Bank of New York Mellon said on Monday that it had hired Charles W. Scharf, the former top executive of Visa and a veteran banker with experience at Citigroup, Bank One and JPMorgan Chase, as its new chief executive.

title: Meghan Ball, Robert Dudley III
description: Meghan Jean Ball and Robert Whittier Dudley III were married on July 15 at St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Dr. Francis H. Wade, an Episcopal priest and a former rector there, performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Sender, Jenny Sabin
description: Katherine Elizabeth Sender and Jenny Elizabeth Sabin were married July 15 in Ithaca, N.Y. Paulette Rosa, the town clerk and a marriage officer there, officiated at Ms. Sabins apartment. That evening, Philip L. Beesley, a friend of the couple, led them through their vows and an exchange of rings at Danos Heuriger on Seneca, a restaurant in Lodi, N.Y.

title: A Cleanup of Holes in the Wall in Chinas Capital
description: BEIJING  When Chinas leaders began the hurly-burly transition to a market economy, they encouraged dislocated workers to take up their own entrepreneurial pursuits. Many of them started small shops, bars or cafes, in what became known as kai qiang da dong, meaning to open a hole in the wall.

title: Alice Hsieh, Carlton Forbes
description: Alice Chung Hsieh, a daughter of Tammy Lin Hsieh and Dr. Raymond Hsieh of Richmond, Va., was married on July 15 to Carlton Eliot Forbes, a son of Giola D. Forbes and Dr. Ronald O. Forbes of Midlothian, Va. Judge Raymond J. Lohier Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, for whom the groom served as a law clerk from 2015 to 2016, officiated at the Hofheimer Building, an event space in Richmond.

title: Eriko Tamura, Nicholas Danilevsky
description: Eriko Tamura and Nicholas Danilevsky were married July 15 in Hong Kong. A deputy registrar officiated at the Cotton Tree Drive Marriage Registry, in a ceremony witnessed by the brides father, Dr. Yoichi Tamura, and the grooms brother, Alexander Danilevsky.

title: From the L.P.G.A. to Congress, Dress Code as a Cause Clbre
description: And so we come to yet another chapter in the continuing opus of dress code in the late twenty-teens.

title: Delta Air Lines Fires Back at Ann Coulter on Twitter, but Refunds Her $30
description: The conservative commentator Ann Coulter unleashed a barrage of criticism about Delta Air Lines on Twitter after she was moved to a different seat on a flight on Saturday, prompting the company to publicly return fire and call her comments unnecessary and unacceptable.

title: Mario Palumbo, Stefan Gargiulo
description: Mario Joseph Palumbo Jr. and Stefan Gargiulo were married July 11 at their apartment in New York. Philip E. Aarons, a friend of the couple who is a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: In South Asian Social Castes, a Living Lab for Genetic Disease
description: In certain states in southern India, anesthesiologists know to ask anyone undergoing surgery whether they belong to the Vysya, a regional group traditionally associated with traders and businesspeople.

title: A Perfect Dinner
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: The Healthcare Debacle: The Roles of Ignorance and Evil
description: The important things to understand about the Republican health care bill are that it is (a) a cruel assault on the health and financial security of tens of millions of Americans (b) being sold via a campaign of lies that is unprecedented in US politics. Defeating this bill, and/or making its supporters pay a massive political price, is priority #1.

title: Why Animals Avoid Munching on Ferns
description: Q. Do ferns have predators? I dont see insects eating them, nor do deer forage on them.

title: For 75 Years, a Mechanic Has Helped Keep Planes Aloft
description: Azriel Blackman, an airline mechanic for American Airlines, is not allowed to climb ladders, drive on the airfield at Kennedy International Airport or even use any tools.

title: 5 George Romero Films to Remember
description: George A. Romero, the maverick film director who died Sunday, brought zombies into our cultural consciousness decades before those in The Walking Dead were even crawling. Heres a look at five of his most memorable films.

title: You May Not Know His Name, but Youve Seen His Pictures of Sarah Bernhardt
description: THE GREAT NADAR The Man Behind the Camera By Adam Begley Illustrated. 248 pp. Tim Duggan Books. $28.

title: The Campaigns, Causes and Controversies of Five American Radicals
description: YOUNG RADICALS In the War for American Ideals By Jeremy McCarter 368 pp. Random House. $30.

title: If You Could Be Someone Else, Would You?
description: Have you ever looked at someone elses life with envy, just enough envy that you wish for a moment or two (or longer) that you could be them? Michelle Obama with her combination of grace and passion; George Clooney with his stylish attractiveness and ironic humor; Usain Bolt or Lionel Messi or some other icon of sport.

title: Wine Shop With Neighboring Bar Opens in Brooklyn
description: Mahesh Lekkala owns five liquor stores in New Jersey, one of which has a wine bar. Now he has brought his chain, Wine Legend, to Downtown Brooklyn. The sleek shop and the wine bar are separated by a wall, and each has its own entrance, to conform to New York liquor laws. The Wine Legend shop sells a variety of fine wines, as well as bargain bottles. The bar serves cocktails, wines by the glass and some rare spirits, like Pappy Van Winkle rye, by the ounce. Small plates, including crostini and sandwiches, are prepared by the chef Bryan Gregg: Wine Legend, 166 Myrtle Avenue (bar entrance on Fleet Place), Brooklyn, 347-422-0015, winelegend.com/ny.

title: Gay Rights Groups Seek One More Win From Justice Kennedy
description: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, the greatest judicial champion of gay rights in the nations history, will turn 81 on Sunday. Rumors that he would retire in June turned out to be wrong, but he will not be on the Supreme Court forever.

title: Subway Track Fire Sends 9 to Hospital and Snarls Morning Commute
description: During a summer of transit misery in New York City, a subway track fire in Upper Manhattan on Monday morning sent nine people to the hospital and snarled trains across the city.

title: Houston Braces for Another Brush With the Peril of Zika
description: HOUSTON  With 4.5 million people in a hot, muggy metropolis built atop a bayou, Americas fourth-largest city, Houston, is a perfect target for the mosquito-borne Zika virus. But it may be better prepared than any other urban center to stop an outbreak.

title: Mysterious Document Is Latest Blow for Dalian Wanda
description: SHANGHAI  A mysterious document circulating on Chinese social media purported that regulators had warned state-run banks against financing several overseas deals by the conglomerate, Dalian Wanda Group. Then a credit-rating agency expressed skepticism about the companys debt.

title: Jordanian Sentenced to Life in Prison for Killing 3 U.S. Soldiers
description: A Jordanian soldier was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison on Monday for the deaths of three United States soldiers whom he shot at an air base in November.

title: The Speed of Silence
description: The roar of big engines was replaced by a whir over the weekend as the Formula E circuit, which uses electric-powered cars, visited Brooklyn.

title: Teenage Golfer Misses Out on $540,000 After U.S. Open Finish
description: Hye-Jin Choi finished second in the United States Womens Open over the weekend. It was a star-making performance for a 17-year-old and seemed to be well-timed, financially. The event had the largest prize money in womens golf history, and second place was worth $540,000.

title: In George Romeros Zombie Films, the Living Were a Horror Show, Too
description: The director George A. Romero, whose six zombie movies represent a towering landmark of horror, died on Sunday of lung cancer. Our critics Jason Zinoman and A.O. Scott dig into his legacy and influence.

title: A Match Made in Baking and Blue Ribbons
description: ATLANTA  Some married couples may vacation in Japan or hike the Appalachian Trail. Chris Taylor and Paul Arguins idea of a dream trip involves a rented condo with a good oven and a nearby pie competition.

title: Trump Tweets Thats Politics! About Sons Meeting With Russian Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON  He ran on a promise to end politics as usual.

title: When Following the Flock Is Not a Winning Strategy
description: We have been taught that there is safety in numbers, and sometimes that is true.

title: China Censors Winnie-the-Pooh on Social Media
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government routinely censors discussion of weighty issues like Tibet, Taiwan and human rights abuses.

title: Man Who Pushed Passenger to His Death on Subway Tracks Is Acquitted
description: It was a grisly scene that combined two deep-seated preoccupations for many New Yorkers: the fear of encountering drunk or deranged people on the subway and the terror of being pushed onto a subway track.

title: Almonds With a Luxurious Twist
description: Almonds, sea salt and a dusting of Italian black truffles work together in this addictive snack, to serve with cocktails or to guard for selfish use. The generous 18-ounce tin also makes a superb housewarming gift: Squirrel Brand Italian Black Truffle Almonds, $23.99 for 18 ounces, $28.99 in paper gift box; $46.99 for 36 ounces in wooden gift box, squirrelbrand.com.

title: The Bolshoi, Under the Exacting Eye of Makhar Vaziev
description: MOSCOW  Soon after becoming the ballet director at the Bolshoi Theater, Makhar K. Vaziev installed a large flat-screen television next to his desk that allows him to monitor the rehearsal rooms and the two main stages  the screen divided into nine squares.

title: Tillersons Grand Renovation Plan in State Department Gets Assistance
description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson is moving ahead with plans to restructure his department, and has hired two consulting groups to assist with the process, according to a cable sent to embassies around the world.

title: How a Warming Climate Will Trouble Air Travel
description: Rising temperatures and more frequent heat waves could force up to 30 percent of airplanes to delay takeoffs in the coming decades, causing cancellations, missed connections and other hassles for passengers, and dealing a financial blow to the industry, a new study finds.

title: Short Films on View at Food and Drink Museum
description: James Boo, a filmmaker, has made more than 30 one-minute films about New Yorkers and their various food traditions. Eight of the films will play at the Museum of Food and Drink in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, from July 27 to Sept. 3. For opening night, Mr. Boo will moderate a panel with Denisse Lina Chavez of El Atoradero, Michael Rogak of JoMart Chocolates, and Helen You of Dumpling Galaxy. Panelists will provide food at the opening-night reception: 1 Minute Meal: Stories of Food and Community in New York, July 27 from 6:30 to 8 p.m., $15 ($10 for students and seniors), 62 Bayard Street (Lorimer Street), 718-387-2845, mofad.org.

title: Jay-Zs 4:44 Gets a Wide Release, and an Easy Trip to No. 1
description: Never underestimate Jay-Z.

title: Swedish Gadget Crushes Spices With a Few Twists
description: If you are ready to grind your own dry rub for summer barbecues, here is a basic gadget from Sweden, almost Paleolithic in its simplicity, that is up to the task. Put whole spices in this cast-iron container, add the matching cup and turn it to grind. The weight and the rough-textured iron are enough to break down the spices. You can then store or serve your freshly ground seasoning in the cup, which has a cork stopper: Skeppshult Cast-Iron Spice Grinder, $58, healdsburgshed.com.

title: Senator McCains Health, and Americas
description: To the Editor:

title: Three TV Shows to Stream This Week
description: I love a far-flung show that takes me to distant lands, or a romantic time-traveling fantasy, or a cartoon horse, or heck, a real-live horse. But now that Sunday nights are bringing me both Game of Thrones and Twin Peaks, I find myself craving something a little more real  a balance, I guess, to the grandiosity and abstraction of last night.

title: Ice Cream Cakes Riff on a Childhood Favorite
description: This strawberry-vanilla ice cream cake takes its inspiration from a Good Humor bar. Its one of the flavors that Salvatore Lo Buglio, the head baker at Little Cupcake Bakeshop, has started making for summer. An almost surreal blue velvet cake filled with blueberry ice cream and coated with lavender and green crumbs is another. He also bakes Key lime, red velvet, vanilla bean, Brooklyn blackout and espresso brownie cakes: $49 for a seven-inch ice cream cake, Little Cupcake Bakeshop in NoLIta, and in Bay Ridge and Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, littlecupcakebakeshop.com.

title: Anti-Violence Activist Is Fatally Shot in Chicago
description: He was known as the Mayor of 95th Street, an angular figure in a cap and blazer who was a fixture of the streets of his Chicago neighborhood. He was an activist who tried to help young people rise above the citys unrelenting gun violence.

title: Three TV Shows to Stream This Week
description: Now that Sunday nights mean Game of Thrones and Twin Peaks, Watchings TV critic is craving shows that feel a little more real.

title: 27 Contact Lenses Are Found in Womans Eye, Doctors Report
description: [Like the Science Times page on Facebook. | Sign up for the Science Times newsletter.]

title: Appeals Court Wrestles With When an Error Requires a New Trial
description: When the Supreme Court announces a decision in a white-collar case, its statements about the law are not necessarily pellucid descriptions of what is permissible.

title: Beer Makers Who Used Other Breweries Are Opening Their Own
description: Chris Lohring surveyed Americas beer scene in 2010 and decided to play the contrarian. Rather than mimic the popular and potent stouts and India pale ales, he would specialize in low-alcohol, high-taste session beers, as he called them.

title: I Just Got Hit by Lightning
description: James Church called 911 after he was struck by lightning on Jan. 7.

title: A New Mike Bartlett Play and a Twilight Zone Adaptation Are Planned at Almeida
description: LONDON  A new play by Mike Bartlett, the author of King Charles III, and a stage adaptation of The Twilight Zone, the 1960s television series, are among the offerings in the Almeida Theaters 2017-18 season, announced on Monday. The artistic director of the Almeida, in London, Rupert Goold, who directed King Charles III, will also direct Mr. Bartletts Albion, described in a statement as being set in the ruins of a garden in rural England.

title: Do You Know Anyone in This 60s Detroit Photograph?
description: The New York Times is asking readers for their help in identifying the people in this photograph taken on July 24, 1967, in Detroit, where racial tensions had led to riots.

title: Where to Watch 3 Things Starring the New Doctor on Doctor Who
description: Behold your newest Time Lord: Jodie Whittaker will be the 13th Doctor in the Doctor Who franchise, the BBC announced this weekend. Shes the first woman to take on the role. Peter Capaldi, the 12th Doctor, will make his final appearance on Dec. 25, in the shows Christmas special.

title: Adding New Fonts to the Computer
description: Q. I want to buy a new font online for my Mac, but how do I get it on my system?

title: Procter & Gambles Board Could Use a Fresh Member
description: Nelson Peltz, the corporate agitator, is opting for the close shave at Procter & Gamble.

title: Dropping Out of College Into Life
description: I never pegged you for a dropout, a family friend said when I moved back home to sleepy Owensboro, Ky., after my freshman year of college.

title: Senator Who Made Headlines for Breast-Feeding Resigns. Also: Malcolm Turnbulls Theatrical Security Announcement.
description: The Breakdown puts a selection of Australias daily news into context. Todays picks:

title: Daily Report: Exploring Facebooks Gated Communities
description: Facebook isnt just one giant meeting place. It is also full of gated communities  private groups that the company is emphasizing more these days.

title: Hong Kong and Taiwan Dont See Eye to Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: Uber Shirks Its Duty to Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hotel Policies Mean a Late Cancellation Will Cost You
description: Business travel can be unpredictable: Flights can be delayed, meetings rescheduled or assignments changed  sometimes with little notice.

title: 5 Ways to Get Good Customer Service From an Airline
description: Over the weekend, the conservative commentator Ann Coulter posted a series of tweets, each more scathing than the last, criticizing Delta for moving her to a different seat. While her complaints were fairly successful, leading the airline to refund her the extra $30 it cost to sit an a row with extra leg-room, the carrier also labeled her actions inappropriate. The exchange raised questions even for those passengers who arent as politically polarizing as Ms. Coulter: What is the most effective way to get good customer service?

title: National Collegiates Audit of P.H.E.A.A.
description: The beneficial owner of National Collegiates student loan trusts conducted an audit of the loans servicer. Crucial paperwork needed to collect on the loans in court is missing, according to the auditors report.

title: As Paperwork Goes Missing, Private Student Loan Debts May Be Wiped Away
description: Tens of thousands of people who took out private loans to pay for college but have not been able to keep up payments may get their debts wiped away because critical paperwork is missing.

title: The Summer Bucket List of a 35-Year-Old Woman
description: Late last week, the summer bucket list of a highly ambitious Pittsburgh teenager was reportedly discovered in an Urban Outfitters dressing room. Some items, written in green marker, include: buy 7 bikinis, pet a giraffe, go ape and get drunk all the time. (N.B.: The last one was completed as of the lists discovery.)

title: In Russia, Battle Between Rosneft and Private Firm Stirs Investment Worries
description: MOSCOW  Sistema and its owner had for years assiduously steered clear of politics in Russia, hoping to avoid the kind of legal issues that often dog high-profile businesses here. But as it has grown into the countrys largest privately owned conglomerate, it has found itself mired in a multi-billion-dollar legal battle.

title: John McCain, North Korea, Russia: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Lawyer for Hasidic Man Convicted in Assault Calls Him a Scapegoat
description: A lawyer for the only defendant tried and convicted in a gang assault in Brooklyn that left a black man blind in one of his eyes has appealed her clients guilty verdict, claiming he was a scapegoat in the attack and there was insufficient evidence to prove he was involved.

title: Harvards Graduate Theater Program Halts Admissions for 3 Years
description: Harvards graduate program in theater will suspend admissions for the next three years, a spokeswoman wrote in an email on Monday  a highly unusual move that has left students and alumni reeling.

title: Mafia in Italy Siphons Huge Sums From Migrant Centers
description: ISOLA DI CAPO RIZZUTO, Italy  The government provided millions of euros to care for the migrants who had arrived at the reception center at Italys toe after traveling across deserts, war zones or choppy seas. But on many days, they were served little more than rancid chicken. Some did not eat at all when the food ran out.

title: Wheres Rey? Despite Uproar, Hasbro Makes Her Monopoly Game Piece Hard to Find
description: Reys courage, suffer-no-fools attitude and skill with a lightsaber in Star Wars: The Force Awakens made her a heroine of those who had long grown tired of seeing women play second fiddle in action movies.

title: Bob Wolff Described Perfection, and Often Hit the Right Notes
description: In 1990, I mentioned to my friend Rick Wolff that I was thinking of writing a book about Don Larsens perfect game in the 1956 World Series. I think you should speak to my dad, Rick said. He was there. He called the game.

title: The Latest in Web Design? Retro Websites Inspired by the 90s
description: To navigate the website for Arcade Fires coming album, Everything Now, users need to click through a cluttered cascade of Windows 98-style pop-ups.

title: Ants, Dutiful Escape Artists, Build Towers in Constant Flux
description: Fire ants build rafts, composed of themselves, to escape floods. As it turns out, they can also build towers. And for David Hu, an engineering professor at Georgia Tech, that turned out to be trouble.

title: The Master of Kompromat Believed to Be Behind Trump Jr.s Meeting
description: MOSCOW  The salacious video, of a naked man in bed with two women, was one of the most prominent examples of kompromat, the Russian art of spreading damaging information to discredit a rival or an enemy, in recent Russian history.

title: The Houston Rockets Are for Sale, and They Will Not Be Cheap
description: The Houston Rockets are for sale, the teams president, Tad Brown, announced Monday, sending shockwaves across the N.B.A. and fueling speculation that the team could draw the highest price ever paid for an American sports franchise.

title: Ants Among Elephants, a Memoir About the Persistence of Caste
description: ANTS AMONG ELEPHANTSAn Untouchable Family and the Making of Modern IndiaBy Sujatha Gidla306 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $28.

title: Horror Vacuis Spring/Summer 2018 Collection
description: A German brand that makes pajamas and other items in vibrant prints.

title: Brand to Know: The Vibrant Line Inspired by 600-Year-Old Pajamas
description: I cant imagine living or even working in an empty white room, says the designer Anna Heinrichs from her studio in Munich, Germany. A love of detail is love for a full life. Her maximalist sensibility also manifests itself in Horror Vacui, a womens wear label she founded in 2012. Its a Latin expression which describes the human instinct to decorate, the urge to fill a vacant space with all kinds of details, she notes.

title: Review: Death of a Salesman, Diluted by Too Many Experiments
description: Willy Loman has been smashing up his car and gassing himself on the boiler for nearly 70 years. A little man with big dreams and bigger regrets, he has rarely stepped offstage since Arthur Millers Death of a Salesman opened in 1949. Now, Willy is back in his native Brooklyn, courtesy of Theater Mitu at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and hes acting pretty strangely  scurrying around in a wrinkly white mask, singing many of his lines, arguing with a refrigerator. Attention must be paid? Sure. Who doesnt like a talking appliance? But this Death of a Salesman revival eclipses the classic instead of illuminating it.

title: Trump Says He Has Signed More Bills Than Any President, Ever. He Hasnt.
description: WASHINGTON  To hear President Trump tell it, his first six months in the White House should be judged in part by the legislation he has signed into law.

title: Meet Archie Warhol, the Art Worlds Second-Most-Famous Dachshund
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa.  Hed come down here for the weekend, but I dont think he was too crazy about the country, the painter Jamie Wyeth recalled, wryly, of Andy Warhols visits to the bucolic southeastern Pennsylvania farm where Mr. Wyeth still lives. By the 1970s, when a joint show saw each man painting a portrait of the other, sparking one of the art worlds unlikeliest friendships, Warhol was famous for many things. Being a nature enthusiast was not one of them.

title: Democrats Perfect Art of Delay While Republicans Fume Over Trump Nominees
description: WASHINGTON  When Senate Democrats in 2013 drastically weakened the ability to filibuster presidential nominees, it seemed as if they were creating a glide path for a president whose party controlled the Senate to speed through confirmations.

title: A Daytime Dance Party That Celebrates Black Diversity
description: They wore lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender slogans, and cowboy fringe, polo shirts and jackets bedazzled with Swarovski crystals. There were Afros and head wraps, and bodies covered in body paint or nothing at all. They danced to layered, percussive beats, the music vibrant and pulsing.

title: Ornette Colemans Innovations Are Celebrated at Lincoln Center
description: In Ornette Colemans most mythic period, from the late 1950s into the early 60s, he released a run of albums for Atlantic Records that bent the blues-based sound of Charlie Parker into a looser and more inclusive style  all molded around Colemans bright and pure alto saxophone sound. These were years of intense creative release; by their end, Coleman had established an understanding of whats now called free jazz.

title: Review: Nelsons Turns Tanglewood Into Bayreuth-in-the-Berkshires
description: LENOX, Mass.  Andris Nelsons is absent from the Wagner festival at Bayreuth again this season. Its the second year in a row that this devoted Wagnerian has withdrawn from performances there, after a spat  sorry, a differing approach in various matters, as he said  with Bayreuths music director, Christian Thielemann.

title: John McCain, Donald Trump, North Korea: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: As Workouts Intensify, a Harmful Side Effect Grows More Common
description: Three years ago, Christina DAmbrosio went to her first spin class, pedaling fast on a stationary bike to the rhythms of popular music as an instructor shouted motivation.

title: Kermit the Frog Performer and Disney Spar Over an Ugly Muppet Firing
description: The longtime voice of Kermit the Frog squared off against executives at Disney on Monday over the companys decision to fire him after almost three decades of bringing that beloved Muppet to life.

title: U.S. to Release Up to 15,000 New Visas for Seasonal Workers
description: LOS ANGELES  The Department of Homeland Security announced on Monday that it will release up to 15,000 additional seasonal visas, known as H-2B visas, to businesses that prove they will be severely hampered without foreign workers.

title: Ex-Officer Is Indicted on Murder Charge in Killing of Black Teenager
description: A white former police officer in a Dallas suburb was indicted by a grand jury on a murder charge for fatally shooting an unarmed black high school freshman in April with a high-powered rifle as the teenager and four others drove away from a house party, prosecutors said Monday.

title: Antiquities Dealer Sues Wall Street Journal Over ISIS Article
description: A leading antiquities dealer sued The Wall Street Journal on Monday, asserting he had been damaged by an article in May that said he was under investigation for possibly trafficking in artifacts looted by ISIS.

title: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal Duel, Once Again, for Supremacy
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Three Grand Slam tournaments down, one to go, and the only men who have won major singles titles are Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.

title: Wm. Theodore de Bary, Renowned Columbia Sinologist, Dies at 97
description: Wm. Theodore de Bary, a venerable Columbia University educator and distinguished scholar of China who was credited with broadening the way colleges nationwide study Asia, died on Friday at his home in Tappan, N.Y. He was 97.

title: U.S. Calls for Much Better Deal in Nafta Overhaul Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Claiming it wants to negotiate a much better deal for all Americans, the Trump administration on Monday revealed its most detailed list of objectives to date for an overhaul of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada.

title: Colleagues of Princeton University Scholar Convicted of Spying in Iran Express Shock
description: Colleagues of an American student from Princeton University who was jailed in Iran on spying charges expressed shock on Monday, calling him a gifted and innocent history scholar whose ordeal has traumatized his family and community.

title: To the Man in the Hard Hat on Eighth Avenue
description: Dear Diary:

title: After Grisly Killings in Pennsylvania, a Quick Deal to Spare Execution
description: The police had been investigating the disappearance of four men in Pennsylvania for only a week when prosecutors sprang a deal on their chief suspect: Confess to murder and help the investigation, and avoid the death penalty.

title: Ohad Naharin to Step Down as Batsheva Dance Company Artistic Director
description: Ohad Naharin, who has led the Batsheva Dance Company in Tel Aviv since 1990 and has established the troupe as one of the worlds great dance ensembles, will step down as its artistic director in September 2018, the company announced late last week. The position will be taken by Gili Navot, a former Batsheva dancer and rehearsal director, while Mr. Naharin will continue to hold the position of house choreographer.

title: As Party Drifts Left, Pragmatic Democratic Governors Have Eye on White House
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Many elected Democrats have drifted left since the partys shattering defeat last November, turning to a brand of progressive politics that is closer to Senator Bernie Sanderss democratic socialism than the more market-friendly liberalism that characterized the Obama era.

title: Quotation of the Day: Town on the Edge
description: We are living on borrowed time.

title: George Romeros Zombie Apocalypse
description: The visionary horror film director George Romero, who died on Sunday at the age of 77, got the last laugh on critics who sought to bury his black-and-white classic Night of the Living Dead when it first stoked Americas nightmares in 1968. Filmed partly by amateurs on a budget that would not suffice as lunch money in todays Hollywood, the movie founded a genre, introducing the zombies who are now synonymous with the apocalypse and ubiquitous in video games, novels, movies and television shows.

title: De Blasio Keeps Fund-Raising Lead, but a Republican Makes Some Gains
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio continues to maintain a sizable financial advantage over all his likely challengers as he runs for re-election in New York, having brought in $414,123 in contributions and spent nearly as much over the last two months, according to a campaign fund-raising report filed on Monday.

title: When Syndergaard and Harvey Play Catch, Every Throw Is Fraught
description: Two young men found their gloves, grabbed a ball and played catch on a sunny afternoon in a city park on Monday. They said it felt good to throw again. It had been a while. They agreed they should do it more often.

title: Health Care Overhaul Collapses as Two Republican Senators Defect
description: WASHINGTON  Two more Republican senators declared on Monday night that they would oppose the Senate Republican bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, killing, for now, a seven-year-old promise to overturn President Barack Obamas signature domestic achievement.

title: Knicks Leaders Talk Defense and Tiptoe Around Puzzle of Carmelo Anthony
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It took less than 90 seconds on Monday for Steve Mills, the Knicks newly anointed team president, to succinctly describe a vision of the future for his victory-challenged club.

title: Family Asks: Why Did Minneapolis Police Kill Australian 911 Caller?
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Family members and friends of a woman who was killed by a Minneapolis police officer voiced anger and frustration on Monday that the authorities had not offered any explanation of how an unarmed womans own call to 911, to report a possible assault, led to her being fatally shot in the alley behind her home.

title: Four Arrested in Gang-Related Killings on Long Island, Court Documents Say
description: Four people have been arrested in the killings of four young Latino men on Long Island on the night of April 11, according to federal court documents that were unsealed on Monday.

title: Meet Apples New Emojis: Zombies, Hijabs and Sandwiches Included
description: Do we really need an emoji for throwing up? Whether we do or not, were getting one.

title: Defendants Cant Be Jailed Solely Because of Inability to Post Bail, Judge Says
description: The chief judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County, Ill., issued an order on Monday that bail-reform advocates hope will be a turning point in the national controversy over requiring defendants to pay more money than they can afford in order to be set free on bail before their trials.

title: U.S. and Chinese Executives to Meet on Nations Economic Relations
description: Leaders of major United States companies with deep ties to China will meet on Tuesday with their Chinese counterparts to try to ease the increasingly rocky economic relationship between the countries.

title: At Knicks Facility, Hopeful Talk and Lessons Learned (or Maybe Not)
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Take 44, in which the Knicks try to get it right, again, again, again, again and so on and so forth.

title: Why Nelson Peltz Wants P.&G. to See Him as a Constructivist
description: Nelson Peltz hates being called an activist, let alone a corporate raider.

title: S. Allen Counter, Who Championed an Unsung Black Explorer, Dies at 73
description: S. Allen Counter, a Harvard neurobiologist and explorer who reclaimed the reputation of Matthew A. Henson, a black explorer on Robert E. Pearys 1909 expedition to the North Pole, and tracked down his descendants in Greenland, died on Wednesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73.

title: Cleverness Thought of Too Late
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  A fairly laborious workout today, but not because the puzzle is a slog. Its because we are being asked to climb stairs in Michael Hawkinss puzzle.

title: Trump Recertifies Iran Nuclear Deal, but Only Reluctantly
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump agreed on Monday to certify again that Iran is complying with an international nuclear agreement that he has strongly criticized, but only after hours of arguing with his top national security advisers, briefly upending a planned announcement as a legal deadline loomed.

title: Board Member Exodus Hits Hampton Creek, a Healthy Food Start-Up
description: Nearly the entire board of Hampton Creek, a high-profile food start-up responsible for the Just Mayo condiment, resigned last month, leaving the companys founder and chief executive, Josh Tetrick, as its only member.

title: When the President Travels, Whos Allowed to Join Him?
description: When the president goes on a trip, he takes a varied entourage. A group of his senior aides accompanies him, usually including national security, domestic or economic advisers, speechwriters and others, depending on the length of the trip and its purpose. But 13 members of the news media, known as the protective press pool, also take seats on Air Force One, representing the worlds of wire services, print newspapers, news sites, broadcast television and radio, as well as photographers.

title: Mets Cant Escape Ghosts of a Dejecting Playoff Loss
description: When the St. Louis Cardinals starting lineup was announced Monday night, starting pitcher Adam Wainwright was mildly booed by the Citi Field crowd, apparently still harboring ill will 11 years after he struck out Carlos Beltran to end Game 7 of the 2006 National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium.

title: California Extends Climate Bill, Handing Gov. Jerry Brown a Victory
description: LOS ANGELES  California lawmakers voted Monday to extend a cap-and-trade program until 2030, ending a legislative standoff that had threatened a critical component of the states pioneering efforts to reduce climate-altering emissions.

title: Corrections: July 18, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Old Truth Trips Up G.O.P. on Health Law: A Benefit Is Hard to Retract
description: WASHINGTON  In the end, Republicans relearned a lesson that has bedeviled them since the New Deal: An American entitlement, once established, can almost never be retracted.

title: A Former Yes Addict Confronts the Pain of Recovery
description: This column is an edited excerpt from the Dear Sugars podcast, an advice program hosted by Steve Almond and Cheryl Strayed. The audio contains an extended conversation, more letters, and special guest Oprah Winfrey. If youre reading on desktop, click the play button below to listen. Mobile readers can find Dear Sugars on the Podcasts app (iPhone and iPad) or Radio Public (Android and tablet).

title: At the Tate Modern, Art and Play
description: Explore the newest wing of the Tate Modern in London, where experiential work encourages museumgoers to interact with the art.

title: What to Read Before You Hit Europes Museums
description: As anyone who has been to the Louvre in Paris or the Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid knows, these institutions can have an outsize effect on a city. Travelers are drawn by the art, of course, but also by the architecture and historical relics within its walls. Below, one book looks at how old master paintings have influenced the development of museums, while another offers a guided tour across Europe.A third, set largely in the Louvre, is a breathless thriller readers will devour on a long flight.

title: The Tate Modern and the Battle for Londons Soul
description: I recently found myself staring into a strangers living room, waiting for something beautiful to happen.

title: On Tours Mountain Roads, Beer, Baguettes and, Briefly, Bikes
description: MONT DU CHAT, France  A white-haired man was dancing naked in the middle of the mountain road, his sunburned body rocking imprecisely to a pop song pounding from a set of speakers. His halfhearted attempt to cover himself with one hand as he swayed was mostly ineffectual, which only made his friends laugh harder and cover their eyes. Behind them was a 20-foot-long, homemade banner that read, VIVE LE TOUR.

title: Brexit, Migrants, Tour de France: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Weary Yankees Are Greeted by Injury News and a Loss in Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A bedraggled Yankees club arrived at its hotel here on Monday about 4 a.m. Central time, worn out from Sundays day-night doubleheader that concluded four stressful games over three days in Boston.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: Colossal and Frontline: Life on Parole
description: In Colossal, Anne Hathaway stars as a party girl at the end of her rope, whose frustrations have worldwide implications. And Frontline and The New York Times follow some former inmates during their first year of supposed freedom.

title: Tour de France Analysis From Its Most Infamous Rider: Lance Armstrong
description: If NBCs broadcast of the Tour de France isnt making the three-week race must-see TV for you, theres an online recap show that might be a perfect alternative.

title: The Right and Left React to the Collapse of the Health Care Bill, and More
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: After Decades of War, Colombian Farmers Face a New Test: Peace
description: LOS ROS, Colombia  Every three months or so, Javier Tupaz, a father of six, heads downhill from his clapboard home to work in his cocaine laboratory.

title: When Education Is Hijacked by War
description: After witnessing teachers, pupils and schools caught in the crossfire of war, Diego Ibarra Snchez began working on Hijacked Education, which examines how constant conflict has upended education.

title: In Congress, Obstructionists Are Obstructing Themselves
description: Republican legislative leaders are in a bind. While they appear to have failed for now in their goal of destroying the Affordable Care Act, their eagerness to shower tax breaks on the wealthy at the expense of health coverage for millions of Americans has crimped their ability to pass other fiscal legislation.

title: Getting Radical About Inequality
description: Im not in the habit of recommending left-wing French intellectuals, but Im beginning to think that Pierre Bourdieu is helpful reading in the age of Trump. He was born in 1930, the son of a small-town postal worker. By the time he died in 2002, he had become perhaps the worlds most influential sociologist within the academy, and largely unknown outside of it.

title: Wall Street Profits by Putting Investors in the Slow Lane
description: Wall Street has developed a new way, clouded in obscurity, to fleece the hundreds of millions of Americans who have money invested in company pension plans, mutual funds and insurance policies.

title: A Brighter Future for Electric Cars and the Planet
description: There is simply no credible way to address climate change without changing the way we get from here to there, meaning cars, trucks, planes and any other gas-guzzling forms of transportation. That is why it is so heartening to see electric cars, considered curios for the rich or eccentric or both not that long ago, now entering the mainstream.

title: A Summer Project to Nourish Your Political Soul
description: Righteousness comes easily in these polarized times. We all have reasons for our opinions, and we tend to be surrounded by people who hold similar ones. The more we talk politics, the more confident we can become that were right.

title: How Trump Is Stealthily Carrying Out His Muslim Ban
description: Lost amid the uproar over the Trump administrations travel restrictions on citizens from Muslim-majority countries and the impending showdown at the Supreme Court are the insidious ways that the government has already begun to impose a Muslim ban.

title: Black and White in Vietnam
description: In 1967, the NBC journalist Frank McGee spent nearly a month living with soldiers of the 101st Airborne Division in Vietnam. Though the troops were often engaged in heavy combat, McGee had a different interest: the experiences of African-American soldiers.

title: Escaping Big Pharmas Pricing With Patent-Free Drugs
description: Hows this for a great deal? The United States government funded research and development of a new vaccine against Zika. But the Army, which paid a French pharmaceutical manufacturer for its development, is planning to grant exclusive rights to the vaccine to the manufacturer, Sanofi Pasteur, along with paying Sanofi up to $173 million.

title: When Education Is Hijacked by War
description: In 2014, Diego Ibarra Snchez was photographing at a school in Iraq. The building was pockmarked with craters from mortar shelling that obliterated an Islamic State encampment that had sought refuge there. In one classroom, Iraqi soldiers kicked around the head of an Islamic State fighter like a soccer ball. A severed leg sat atop a desk behind them.

title: Seth Meyers Says Trump Thinks in Cartoons
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: How Steve Bannon and Donald Trump Rode the Honey Badger Into the White House
description: DEVILS BARGAINSteve Bannon, Donald Trump, and the Storming of the PresidencyBy Joshua Green272 pp. Penguin Press. $27.

title: A New Front in the War Over Reproductive Rights: Abortion-Pill Reversal
description: Marie Stettler has a tattoo on her arm that reads Gelobt sei Jesus Christus, in Ewigkeit Amen. Its a German prayer her family used to recite together, and it means Praise be Jesus Christ, for eternity Amen. The family attended Mass weekly, and every Saturday morning at 4:30 they prayed together in front of the Eucharist for an hour. As a teenager in Soda Springs, Idaho, Stettler had a 4.0 G.P.A. and was named Caribou County Junior Miss. She prayed all the time, asking God at each big juncture of her life what he wanted her to do. Her friends, she said, saw her as this Christian gal who is chasing the Lord.

title: Everywhere You Look, Weve Downgraded Real Problems Into Mere Issues
description: There are a great many problems in this world. Among them is the way we talk about problems. Perhaps understandably, the thorniest ones make us cautious and avoidant. So we toss linguistic blankets over them until they become nothing but unexplained lumps in the room.

title: What Will Service Work Look Like Under Amazon?
description: At 9 p.m. Eastern time on July 10, Amazon initiated its annual show of force: Prime Day, a 30-hour exercise in the fullest possible expression of what Amazon can do. The sale, timed to the companys birthday, is marketed with an urgency bordering on panic. Whats for sale? Basically anything. Where is it for sale? Wherever you are. Some sales last the whole prolonged day; others last a few minutes. A car seat. Golf clubs. Jeans and a screen door. Turmeric extract. A gallon of Elmers glue. An Amazon product  the voice-controlled Echo, which can order more products from Amazon. Makeup brushes. Jumper cables. A tablet computer. The shopping experience is at turns euphoric and anxiety-inducing, Amazons already-busy interface teeming with decontextualized blinking numbers: Sunglasses by Hulislem, $16.79, down from $115.95 after a previous discount to $28.99, 86 percent off, ends in 2:08:51, 63 percent already claimed. No? Next. Pro Series Waist Trimmer: $15.16-$18.96, 22 percent claimed, ends in ... 0:00:43. Damn. Time is running out.

title: How to Dine Well  and Properly  in Another Country
description: When youre traveling internationally, eating at local restaurants is an opportunity to learn about that countrys culture and customs, says Gert Kopera, the executive vice president of global restaurants for Hakkasan Group, a collection of 41 restaurants worldwide. But, Mr. Kopera said, dining out can also make travelers uncomfortable. Dining etiquette and traditions vary by country, and if you dont know the customs in the destination youre visiting, he said, its easy to feel like a fish out of water.

When Texas lawmakers gather here for the start of a 30-day special legislative session on Tuesday morning, they will most likely decide the fate of the Texas version of North Carolinas bitterly divisive legislation regulating the access of transgender people to public bathrooms.

These events could threaten to disrupt the free flow of information over the internet.

title: Walter Shaub: How to Restore Government Ethics in the Trump Era
description: Shortly after his inauguration, President George H. W. Bush counseled freshly minted White House appointees that, Its not really very complicated. Its a question of knowing right from wrong, avoiding conflicts of interest, bending over backwards to see that theres not even a perception of conflict of interest. He paired this straightforward declaration with action, establishing unified standards of conduct for the executive branch and resolving his own conflicts of interest. These words and deeds set the tone for ethical governance.

First one party rams through a rigid, convoluted plan that drives up costs though unsustainable mechanisms that are now unraveling. Then the other party pursues fixes that go too far the other way  and again ignores ideas from the other side.
